courses.name: Basic Concepts of Apparel Design and Production
courses.description: Introduction to design techniques, coordination of fabric with design, selection of support materials, and basic understanding of garment assembly operations.

courses.name: Softgoods Retailing
courses.description: Surveys merchandising and retailing principles with specific applications to the softgoods industry.

courses.name: Presentation Techniques for Merchandising
courses.description: This class explores Adobe Creative Suite (Photoshop, Illustrator, and InDesign) as a tool for presentation techniques within the field of fashion merchandising.

courses.name: Professional Seminar
courses.description: Exploration of issues in professional activity/success including: evaluating opportunities, oral and written communication for presenting oneself, the articulation of professional/private life, and professional ethics.

courses.name: Science of Textiles
courses.description: Fundamental concepts of textiles.  Chemical composition, molecular arrangement, and physical structure of natural and manufactured fibers.  Yarn and fabric manufacturing and various finishing techniques.  Impacts of such characteristics and techniques on function, performance, and quality.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Apparel Production
courses.description: Introduction to sewn products industry applications in which students assemble sample garments and products on industrial equipment. Order of operations is emphasized and industry specific software is introduced. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Retail Finance and Merchandise Control
courses.description: Emphasizes assortment and financial planning utilizing computer applications in the retail environment. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.

courses.name: Integrated Apparel Design and Production I
courses.description: A beginning apparel product development course integrating pattern-making, apparel assembly decision-making and materials selection. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: C- or above in T_A_M 2280 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Global Consumers
courses.description: This course uses consumer behavior and cultural frameworks, integrated with critical and creative thinking processes to develop global perspective that is sensitive to diverse consumers' needs and preferences for products and services in the global marketplace. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Apparel and Textile Presentation Techniques
courses.description: Apparel and textile presentation processes. Introduction to a range of traditional and innovative presentation techniques using various media. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Social Appearance in Time and Space
courses.description: An investigation of the motives and meanings that individuals negotiate through the use of dress in presenting themselves as players in complex social contexts. The emphasis is on cross-cultural, historical, and contemporary settings.

courses.name: Social Appearance in Time and Space - Writing Intensive
courses.description: An investigation of the motives and meanings that individuals negotiate through the use of dress in presenting themselves as players in complex social contexts. The emphasis is on cross-cultural, historical, and contemporary settings.

courses.name: History of Western Dress
courses.description: Surveys the history of Western dress from prehistory through the 18th Century.

courses.name: History of Western Dress - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Surveys the history of Western dress from prehistory through the 18th Century.

courses.name: Digital Textile and Apparel Applications
courses.description: Use of computer aided design technology to create designs for textiles and apparel. Includes portfolio development. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.hours: 3Prerequisites or Corequisites: C- or above in T_A_M 2480 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Think Global: Fundamentals of Globalization and Digital Technologies
courses.description: (same as GERMAN 3510, PEA_ST 2810, JOURN 3510, DST 3510). This interdepartmental course serves as one of the core seminars for students pursuing the undergraduate Certificate in Digital Global Studies. The course focuses on the impact of technological change and globalization on cultures around the world from various interdisciplinary perspectives. The course is open to students in any discipline.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Think Global: Fundamentals of Globalization and Digital Technologies - Honors
courses.description: (same as GERMAN 3510H, JOURN 3510H, PEA_ST 2810H, DST 3510H). This interdepartmental course serves as the introductory seminar for students pursuing the Certificate of Digital Global Studies. The course focuses on the impact of technological change and globalization on cultures around the world from various interdisciplinary perspectives.
courses.prerequisites: Honors eligibility required. Restricted to non-Journalism students. Journalism students should enroll in Journalism sides of this course

courses.name: Think Global: Fundamentals of Globalization and Digital Technologies - Honors/Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as GERMAN 3510HW, JOURN 3510HW, PEA_ST 2810HW). This interdepartmental course serves as the introductory seminar for students pursuing the Certificate of Digital Global Studies. The course focuses on the impact of technological change and globalization on cultures around the world from various interdisciplinary perspectives.
courses.prerequisites: Honors eligibility required. Restricted to non-Journalism students. Journalism students should enroll in Journalism sides of this course

courses.name: Think Global: Fundamentals of Globalization and Digital Technologies - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as GERMAN 3510W, PEA_ST 2810W, JOURN 3510W, DST 3510W). This interdepartmental course serves as one of the core seminars for students pursuing the undergraduate Certificate in Digital Global Studies. The course focuses on the impact of technological change and globalization on cultures around the world from various interdisciplinary perspectives. The course is open to students in any discipline.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Recent Trends in Textiles and Apparel Management
courses.description: For upper-class students who wish additional knowledge and understanding in specific subject matter areas.

courses.name: Textiles and Apparel in the Global Economy
courses.description: Economic, social, and political dimensions of the textile complex and trade in a global economy; implications for production, distribution, and consumption of products.

courses.name: Softgoods Quality Evaluation
courses.description: Examination and evaluation of fabric and apparel structures with emphasis on principles of advanced textile performance and quality analysis.  Includes end-use characteristics; price/quality relationships; textile and apparel product standards and specifications; and standard test methods to evaluate comfort, performance, and function of sewn products. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Computer Aided Design
courses.description: Use of computer aided design technology to create designs for textiles and apparel.

courses.name: Retail and Merchandising Analysis
courses.description: This course provides an opportunity to apply the concepts of merchandise planning, financial control, and promotions to real life buying situations.  It will employ a problem-based learning approach. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Integrated Apparel Design and Production II
courses.description: An intermediate apparel product development course integrating pattern-making, apparel assembly decision-making and materials selection. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Technical Design
courses.description: Technical product development for the global sewn products industry. Graded on A-F only basis.

courses.name: 19th and 20th Century Western Dress
courses.description: A study of nineteenth and twentieth century Western dress as influenced by time, place, and culture. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: ENGLSH 1000. Restricted to Textile and Apparel Management majors only

courses.name: 19th and 20th Century Western Dress - Writing Intensive
courses.description: A study of nineteenth and twentieth century Western dress as influenced by time, place, and culture. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: ENGLSH 1000. Restricted to Textile and Apparel Management majors only

courses.name: MultiChannel Retailing in the Digital World
courses.description: Assessing the integration of various retail channels and developing multichannel strategies.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Entrepreneurship
courses.description: This course covers the fundamental principles, practices, and procedures of entrepreneurship in a step-by-step approach, and generates a final business plan. It delves into identifying viable target market through research, appealing to and securing customers, selecting a location, recruiting and retailing great employees and determining how much stock to carry and how to sell it. This course is designed for those who want to consider starting their own retail businesses, but not limited to those who want to reassess the direction of their existing businesses, or to those who want to build tangible as well as intangible entrepreneurial skill sets for their corporate careers. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Topics in Textiles and Apparel Management
courses.description: Selected current topics in field of interest.

courses.name: Problems in Textiles and Apparel Management
courses.description: Selected current problems in field of interest.

courses.name: Seminar in Textiles and Apparel Management
courses.description: Reports and discussion of recent work in area of concentration.

courses.name: Electronic Commerce Applications
courses.description: Integration of theory, design, management, and application processes used in Electronic Commerce.

courses.name: Global Sourcing
courses.description: (cross-leveled with T_A_M 7110). Global sourcing refers to how and where manufactured goods or components will be procured. In today's global softgoods industry, sourcing has become a major competitive strategy for both manufacturers and retailers. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Supply Chain Management
courses.description: This course examines how the supply chain management can be used to gain a competitive advantage in the softgoods industry.

courses.name: Softgoods Brand Management and Promotion
courses.description: (cross-leveled with T_A_M 7300). This course addresses how to build, measure, and manage brands specifically in the softgoods industry. It also covers the strategic implications of developing brand equity toward increasing customer loyalty.

courses.name: The Clothing/Textile Consumer: Research and Analysis
courses.description: Examines the effects of economic, social and marketing factors on the clothing consumption process. Legislative and quality issues related to clothing and textiles are also discussed.

courses.name: Creativity and Problem Solving
courses.description: Exploration of the creative process and sources of inspiration. Emphasis on research, design development for a variety of markets. Graded on A-F basis only.  Prerequisites or Corequsites: T_A_M 3380.

courses.name: International Experiential Learning in Textiles and Apparel
courses.description: International experience of textile and apparel management, including visitation of foreign industries, government agencies, and cultural/historical sites.  Destination may vary. Course may be repeated up to 3 times. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Case Studies in an Inter/Multicultural World
courses.description: (same as GERMAN 4810, PEA_ST 4810, DST 4805).  This inter-departmental course examines the ways in which people across the globe are affected every day by an unprecedented array of linkages that defy geographic and political boundaries.  Also serves as one of the seminars for the certificate in Digital Global Studies.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Field Training in Textiles and Apparel Management
courses.description: Practical aspects of internship experience coordinated with the university curriculum. Available for various areas of emphasis.
courses.prerequisites: 2.5 GPA, T_A_M 2120, instructor's consent, and necessary prerequisite for area of emphasis

courses.name: Readings in Textiles and Apparel Management
courses.description: Selected current readings in field of interest.

courses.name: Apparel Production Management
courses.description: Integration of consumer, trend and aesthetic research to develop and produce a competitive apparel product line using a multifunctional team approach. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Retail Marketing and Merchandising
courses.description: (cross-leveled with T_A_M 7990). Analytical management techniques appropriate for evaluation of retailing productivity. Emphasis on the use of these techniques and others in the development of a comprehensive retail marketing strategy.
courses.hours: 3Prerequisites or Corequisites: T_A_M 2300, ACCTCY 2036 or ACCTCY 2026 or ACCTCY 2010, MRKTNG 3000

courses.name: Experiential Learning in Textiles and Apparel
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with hands-on-experiences in the softgood industry. The purpose is to link classroom learning to business cultural centers, museums, workshops, and /or service learning opportunities achieved through experiential study. Additional field study fees might be applicable, depending on experience. May be repeated for credit. Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent and minimum GPA of 2.5

courses.name: Topics in Clothing and Textiles
courses.description: Selected current topics in field of interest.

courses.name: Problems in Clothing and Textiles
courses.description: Selected current readings in field of interest.
courses.prerequisites: 3000-level course in field of problems and instructor's consent

courses.name: Seminar in Clothing and Textiles
courses.description: Reports and discussion of recent work in area of concentration.

courses.name: Global Sourcing
courses.description: Global sourcing refers to how and where manufactured goods or components will be procured. In today's global softgoods industry, sourcing has become a major competitive strategy for both manufacturers and retailers.

courses.name: Web-Based Marketing Research
courses.description: This project-oriented course will focus on principles of marketing research applicable to textile/apparel online environments.  Students will learn how to develop, utilize, and analyze web-based research.

courses.name: Branding
courses.description: (cross-leveled with T_A_M 4300). This course addresses how to build, measure, and manage brands specifically in the softgoods industry. It also covers the strategic implications of developing brand equity toward increasing customer loyalty.

courses.name: Readings in Clothing and Textiles
courses.description: Readings in recent research material in textiles and/or clothing.
courses.prerequisites: 20 hours in Textile and Apparel Management, and instructor's consent

courses.name: Softgoods Product Development
courses.description: Integration of consumer, trend and aesthetic research to develop and produce a competitive apparel product line using a multi-functional team approach.

courses.name: Retail Marketing and Merchandising
courses.description: (cross-leveled with T_A_M 4990). Analytical management techniques appropriate for evaluation of retailing productivity. Emphasis on the use of these techniques and others in the development of a comprehensive retail marketing strategy.
courses.prerequisites: T_A_M 2300, ACCTCY 2036 or ACCTCY 2026 or ACCTCY 2010, MRKTNG 3000

courses.name: International Experiential Learning in Textiles and Apparel
courses.description: Investigation of the complex interaction of manufacturing, marketing, and merchandising in the apparel industry, achieved through instructional and experiential study.  Includes international or domestic study trip.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Readings in Textiles and Apparel Management
courses.description: Readings in recent research material in textiles and/or clothing.
courses.prerequisites: 20 hours in Textile and Apparel Management, and instructor's consent

courses.name: Topics in Clothing and Textiles
courses.description: Selected current topics in field of interest.

courses.name: Problems in Textiles and Apparel Management
courses.description: Selected current readings in field of interest.
courses.prerequisites: 4000-level course in field of problem and instructor's consent

courses.name: Seminar in Clothing and Textiles
courses.description: Reports and discussion of recent work in area of concentration.

courses.name: Research in Clothing and Textiles
courses.description: Independent research leading to a thesis. Report required.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Supply Chain Management in the Global Softgoods Industry
courses.description: This course examines supply chain management strategies to gain a competitive advantages in the global softgoods industry.

courses.name: Survey of Research in Textile and Apparel Management
courses.description: A survey of current research in textiles and apparel management. Underlying theory, research design and empirical techniques will be analyzed and critiqued.
courses.prerequisites: hours in Statistics and 3 hours in Research Methods

courses.name: Applied Research Procedures and Analyses in Textiles and Apparel
courses.description: Investigation of applied research techniques and analyses used in the field of Textile and Apparel Management.
courses.prerequisites: 3 credits of merchandising, marketing, or microeconomics; 3 credits in computer science and 3 credits in statistics

courses.name: Qualitative Social Research Methods
courses.description: Focus is on the philosophical differences inherent in an interpretivist versus a positivist approach to social research, the strategies and methods of qualitative research, and qualitative research design and criticism. May be repeated twice.

courses.name: Perspectives of 19th and 20th Century Dress
courses.description: A study of nineteenth and twentieth century western dress as influenced by time, place, and culture.

courses.name: Sustainable Softgoods
courses.description: This course examines sustainability in the soft goods industry in the context of cultural, economic, environmental, social, and technological policies and procedures of soft goods industries.  Includes ethics, government policies international labor standards, environmental regulations, company priorities, consumer responsibilities, economic impact, and worker rights.  The importance of establishing leadership for social change will be incorporated.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Readings in Clothing and Textiles
courses.description: Readings in recent research material in textiles and/or clothing.
courses.prerequisites: graduate standing, 20 hours in Textile and Apparel Management, and instructor's consent

courses.name: Topics in Clothing and Textiles
courses.description: Selected current topics in field of interest.

courses.name: Problems in Textiles and Apparel Management
courses.description: Selected current readings in field of interest.
courses.prerequisites: 4000-level course in field of problem and instructor's consent

courses.name: Seminar in Clothing and Textiles
courses.description: Reports and discussion of recent work in area of concentration.

courses.name: Research in Textiles and Apparel Management
courses.description: Independent research leading to dissertation. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Theory Development and Evaluation in Textile and Apparel Research
courses.description: This class examines and analyzes extant theories in textiles and apparel research in systemic manner to be able to construct new theories.   Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Cloth and the Human Experience
courses.description: Examines the social context of dress and other intimate manifestations of daily life using culture as the level of analysis.

courses.name: Textile History Seminar
courses.description: Investigation of research in textile and costume history with emphasis on developing questions, methods of analysis and interpretation appropriate for data sources used.

courses.name: Readings in Clothing and Textiles
courses.description: Readings in recent research material in textiles and/or clothing.
courses.prerequisites: 20 hours in Textile and Apparel Management, and instructor's consent
